Article.ArticleTitle: Long-term trends and affecting factors in the concentrations of criteria air pollutants in South Korea.

AbstractText: Here, we used a novel approach to analyze the trends in the concentrations of six national criteria air pollutants, carbon monoxide (CO), sulfur dioxide (SO<sub>2</sub>), nitrogen dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub>), PM<sub>10</sub>, PM<sub>2.5</sub>, and surface ozone (O<sub>3</sub>), between 2001 and 2018, and the factors affecting the concentrations of CO and SO<sub>2</sub> at the district level in South Korea (Korea) between 2011 and 2016. We considered four factors affecting the concentrations of CO and SO<sub>2</sub>: (1) concentration-to-emission ratio, (2) air pollutant-to-CO<sub>2</sub> emission ratio, (3) carbon intensity, and (4) area-weighted energy supply. We found that the most influencing factors determining the concentrations of CO and SO<sub>2</sub> in Korea were the air pollutant-to-CO<sub>2</sub> emission ratio and the concentration-to-emission ratio. The annual mean concentrations of CO, SO<sub>2</sub>, PM<sub>10</sub>, PM<sub>2.5</sub>, and NO<sub>2</sub> generally decreased, while O<sub>3</sub> levels showed an increasing trend, over the last 18 years in Korea. We also found that NO<sub>2</sub> concentration had strong positive and negative correlations with PM<sub>2.5</sub> and O<sub>3</sub> concentrations, respectively. However, the relationship between O<sub>3</sub> and NO<sub>2</sub> levels showed an inverted U shape under NO<sub>2</sub> super-rich condition (e.g., > 55 ppb in Seoul), and the daily maximum 8-h values (MDA8O<sub>3</sub>) increased in proportion to the NO<sub>2</sub> level under poor NO<sub>2</sub> conditions (e.g., < 25 ppb in Seoul).
